sentence1: So Shannon took the logarithm of the volume in message space occupied by a message and multiplied it by the probability that that message was sent from the source.

sentence2: Shannon determined that the message came from a negative source.
sentence2_translated: Shannon kpɔe be ame gbegblẽ aɖee nɔ nyaa gblɔm.

sentence1: In the fitness landscape, image, mutation, recombination, and selection can conspire to pull evolving populations upward toward the peaks of high fitness.

sentence1: Clearly today's children spend far too many hours in front of the TV set, a circumstance that restricts time available for joint parent-child activities, play, reading, and other worthwhile pursuits.

sentence2: Children today spend more time watching TV than reading.
sentence2_translated: Egbea ɖeviwo zãa ɣeyiɣi geɖe wu ɖe television kpɔkpɔ ŋu wu nuxexlẽ ŋu.

sentence1: Deborah Lipstadt, in her book Denying the Holocaust, wrote that we should not publicly debate unacceptable as well as obviously false claims, and thus she advanced a remedy as powerful as governmental censorship.

sentence1: Once established, neurons begin to take on unique functions by sending out branching  bers, which form elaborate connections with other neurons.

sentence1: The rugged mountains of the Serra de Tramuntana sweep down to the sea so steeply here that there are few points of access and only one harbor and port of any size along the coast.

sentence1: The first Westerner to reach Hawaii was Captain James Cook, the British commander whose mission was to disacover the mythic Northwest Passage linking the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.

sentence2: A church, chapel, and hexagonal tower represent the city's post-war rebirth.

sentence1: As a Protestant, Pierre du Calvet was appointed by the British justice of the peace but then ended up in jail himself for selling supplies and information to the American invaders.
sentence1_translated: Esi Pierre du Calvet nye Protestant ta la, Britaintɔwo tiae be wòanye ŋutifafaʋɔnudrɔ̃la, gake emegbe eya ŋutɔ hã de gaxɔ me le esi wòdzra nuhiahiãwo kple nyatakakawo na Amerika dziɖulawo ta.
sentence2: Pierre was appointed but had to arrest himself for selling to the Americans.
sentence2_translated: Woti Pierre ɖo, gake eva hiã be wòalé eɖokui le esi wòdzra nu na Amerikatɔwo ta.

sentence1: On weekends you can join the locals in the Parque de Palapas, where the strains of rock, salsa, and folk music can blend together into a bewildering cacophony.

sentence1: The find that caught the whole world's imagination was made by one James Wilson Marshall, a carpenter, at John Sutter's sawmill on the American River at Coloma, which lies midway between Sacramento and Lake Tahoe.
sentence1_translated: James Wilson Marshall, si nye atikpala, ye ke ɖe nu si ŋu ame geɖe va nya nu tsoe la ŋu le John Sutter ƒe atikpakpa me le American River si le Coloma, si le Sacramento kple Tahoe Ta me la ƒe domedome.
sentence2: James Wilson Marshall did nothing special.
sentence2_translated: James Wilson Marshall mewɔ naneke si ɖe dzesi o.

sentence1_translated: Enye CIO ƒe dɔ be wòakpɔ nu siwo ŋu wòkpɔ mɔ ɖo la gbɔ eye wòakpe ɖe eŋu be habɔbɔa me tɔ siwo katã nye CIO la nase woƒe agbanɔamedziwo gɔme nyuie.
sentence2: The CIO has many duties, including managing expectations and making sure members understand their responsibilities.
sentence2_translated: Dɔ geɖe le CIO la si, siwo dometɔ aɖewoe nye be wòakpɔ mɔ na nuwo eye wòakpɔ egbɔ be ƒomea me tɔwo se woƒe agbanɔamedziwo gɔme.

sentence1: It is the duty of a CIO to manage expectations and help ensure that all members of a CIO organization have a clear understanding of their responsibilities.
sentence1_translated: Enye CIO ƒe dɔ be wòakpɔ nu siwo ŋu wòkpɔ mɔ ɖo la gbɔ eye wòakpe ɖe eŋu be habɔbɔa me tɔ siwo katã nye CIO la nase woƒe agbanɔamedziwo gɔme nyuie.
sentence2: The CIO has no idea what the responsibilities of members are and isn't responsible for informing them.
sentence2_translated: Ŋutsu si kpɔa nyatakakawo gbɔ menya nusi nye ƒomea me tɔwo ƒe agbanɔamedzi o eye menye eƒe dɔe be wòana woanya o.

sentence1: It is the duty of a CIO to manage expectations and help ensure that all members of a CIO organization have a clear understanding of their responsibilities.

sentence1_translated: Nu ɖeka si sɔ na ame sia ame wɔwɔ menɔa bɔbɔe le dɔ siwo wowɔ kpata me o, abe ale si ko wònɔa bɔbɔe le kɔdzi hã ene.
sentence2: One size fits all when it comes to brief interventions.
sentence2_translated: Ne nya ku ɖe nuwɔwɔ kpuiwo ŋu la, ame sia ame ƒe nɔnɔme sɔ.

sentence1: In other words, when households' existing assets increase in value, people can save less from current income and still achieve their wealth-income target.
sentence1_translated: Ne míagblɔe bubui la, ne aƒemedɔwo ƒe nunɔamesiwo ƒe asixɔxɔ dzi ɖe edzi la, amewo ate ŋu akpɔ ga si wokpɔna fifia dzi akpɔtɔ eye woagaɖo woƒe kesinɔnu ƒe taɖodzinu gbɔ.
sentence2: A household's existing assets have no bearing on the amount of money from income that needs to be saved.
sentence2_translated: Aƒeme ƒe nunɔamesi siwo li fifia mewɔa dɔ aɖeke ɖe ga si wòle be woaɖo ɖi la dzi o.

sentence1: In other words, when households' existing assets increase in value, people can save less from current income and still achieve their wealth-income target.

sentence2: Increased value in existing assets can lower the amount of savings from income that is needed.

sentence1: In other words, when households' existing assets increase in value, people can save less from current income and still achieve their wealth-income target.

sentence1: The next level down, the director of the al Qaeda unit in CIA at the time recalled that he did not think it was his job to direct what should or should not be done.

sentence2: The director didn't want to get involved because he was almost retired.

sentence1: Ramzi Yousef and Khalid Sheikh Mohammed masterminded the 1995 Manila air plot, and KSM helped fund Yousef 's attempt to blow up the World Trade Center in 1993.

sentence1: Between 6:45 and 7:40, Atta and Omari, along with Satam al Suqami, Wail al Shehri, and Waleed al Shehri, checked in and boarded American Airlines Flight 11, bound for Los Angeles.
sentence1_translated: Tso gaƒoƒo 6:45 va ɖo 7:40 la, Atta kple Omari, kpakple Satam al Suqami, Wail al Shehri, kple Waleed al Shehri, ɖo ʋu heɖo American Airlines Flight 11, si ɖo ta Los Angeles.
sentence2: Atta and Omari sat in window seats while the others sat on the isles.
sentence2_translated: Atta kple Omari nɔ zikpuiwo nu esime ame mamlɛawo nɔ teƒe siwo le atsiaƒuwo dzi.

sentence1: Between 6:45 and 7:40, Atta and Omari, along with Satam al Suqami, Wail al Shehri, and Waleed al Shehri, checked in and boarded American Airlines Flight 11, bound for Los Angeles.
sentence1_translated: Tso gaƒoƒo 6:45 va ɖo 7:40 la, Atta kple Omari, kpakple Satam al Suqami, Wail al Shehri, kple Waleed al Shehri, ɖo ʋu heɖo American Airlines Flight 11, si ɖo ta Los Angeles.
sentence2: They attempted to board the flight but Wail al Shehri was detained by security.
sentence2_translated: Wodze agbagba be yewoage ɖe yameʋua me gake dedienɔnɔkpɔlawo lé Wail al Shehri.

sentence1: Between 6:45 and 7:40, Atta and Omari, along with Satam al Suqami, Wail al Shehri, and Waleed al Shehri, checked in and boarded American Airlines Flight 11, bound for Los Angeles.

sentence2: They boarded a flight to Los Angeles before 8:00.

sentence1: The people of the United States hoped to enjoy a peace dividend, as U.S. spending on national security was cut following the end of the Soviet military threat.
sentence1_translated: United States dukɔmeviwo nɔ mɔ kpɔm be yewoakpɔ dzidzedze le ŋutifafa me, elabena woxe Amerika ƒe gazazã ɖe dukɔa ƒe dedienɔnɔ ŋu le Soviet-srafowo ƒe ŋɔdzidoname nu.
sentence2: As the Soviet threat ended the US embarked on a massive military buildup.
sentence2_translated: Esi Soviettɔwo ƒe ŋɔdzidoname nu va yi la, United States dze aʋawɔnu gãwo tutu ɖo.

sentence1: The people of the United States hoped to enjoy a peace dividend, as U.S. spending on national security was cut following the end of the Soviet military threat.

sentence2: Defense budgets were cut by more than fifty billion dollars per year.

sentence1: While the test results for physical search exceeded the national average, both the metal detector and X-ray results were below average.

sentence1: Local newspapers and the few influential satellite broadcasters-like al Jazeera-often reinforce the jihadist theme that portrays the United States as anti-Muslim.

sentence1: Our border screening system should check people efficiently and welcome friends.

sentence1: Our border screening system should check people efficiently and welcome friends.

sentence1: More than 500 million people annually cross U.S. borders at legal entry points, about 330 million of them noncitizens.
sentence1_translated: Ame miliɔn 500 kple edzivɔe toa Amerika ƒe liƒowo dzi yia dukɔ bubuwo me ƒe sia ƒe le mɔ si sɔ nu, eye wo dometɔ miliɔn 330 nye dukɔmevi dzrowo.
sentence2: Only 20,000 people cross the border each year.
sentence2_translated: Ame 20,000 koe toa liƒo la me ƒe sia ƒe.

sentence1: The Director still has no strategy for removing information-sharing barriers and-more than two years since 9/11-has only appointed a working group on the subject.
sentence1_translated: Dɔdzikpɔlaa mekpɔ ɖoɖo aɖeke si dzi wòato aɖe nyatakakamɔnuwo mama ƒe kplamatsedonuwo ɖa o eye - le ƒe eve kple edzivɔ megbe tso 9/11 dzi - dɔdzikpɔhaa ɖo dɔdzikpɔha aɖe ɖe nya sia ŋu ko.
sentence2: Information sharing barriers were still in place after two years.
sentence2_translated: Woganɔ nya siwo wotsi tre ɖe nyatakakamɔnuwo mama ŋu la ɖem le afi ma le ƒe eve megbe.

sentence1: The Director still has no strategy for removing information-sharing barriers and-more than two years since 9/11-has only appointed a working group on the subject.
sentence1_translated: Dɔdzikpɔlaa mekpɔ ɖoɖo aɖeke si dzi wòato aɖe nyatakakamɔnuwo mama ƒe kplamatsedonuwo ɖa o eye - le ƒe eve kple edzivɔ megbe tso 9/11 dzi - dɔdzikpɔhaa ɖo dɔdzikpɔha aɖe ɖe nya sia ŋu ko.
sentence2: The Director did not believe that information sharing barriers should be entirely removed.
sentence2_translated: Dɔdzikpɔlaa mexɔe se be ele be woaɖe mɔxenu siwo hea nyatakakawo dome kadodo vɛ la ɖa keŋkeŋ o.

sentence1: The Director still has no strategy for removing information-sharing barriers and-more than two years since 9/11-has only appointed a working group on the subject.

sentence2_translated: Dɔdzikpɔlaa ɖe mɔxenu siwo katã xe mɔ na nyatakakamɔnuwo mama ɖa enumake.

sentence1: A jet fuel fireball erupted upon impact and shot down at least one bank of elevators.
sentence1_translated: Dzo si tso yameʋuwo me la do le afɔkua me heɖe afɔkpa ɖeka ya teti.
sentence2: The fire was hot enough to melt some of the glass windows in the area.
sentence2_translated: Dzo la xɔ dzo ale gbegbe be wòna fesre siwo le nutoa me la dometɔ aɖewo miã.

sentence1: A jet fuel fireball erupted upon impact and shot down at least one bank of elevators.

sentence1: The operators were not given any information about the inability to conduct rooftop rescues and therefore could not advise callers that they had essentially been ruled out.
sentence1_translated: Womeɖe gbeƒã na dɔwɔlawo be womate ŋu awɔ xɔtudɔ le xɔta o, eya ta womate ŋu agblɔ na ame siwo yɔa wo be womate ŋu awɔ dɔ sia o.
sentence2: Helocopters could not be flown near the roofs due to fires in the area.
sentence2_translated: Womeɖea mɔ na helikopterwo be woado ɖe xɔtawo ŋu o le dzo si le xɔta la ta.

sentence1: The operators were not given any information about the inability to conduct rooftop rescues and therefore could not advise callers that they had essentially been ruled out.
sentence1_translated: Womeɖe gbeƒã na dɔwɔlawo be womate ŋu awɔ xɔtudɔ le xɔta o, eya ta womate ŋu agblɔ na ame siwo yɔa wo be womate ŋu awɔ dɔ sia o.
sentence2: The operators did not know that rooftop rescues were impossible.
sentence2_translated: Ame siwo wɔa dɔ le xɔta la menya be womate ŋu axɔ na ame le xɔta o.

sentence1: The operators were not given any information about the inability to conduct rooftop rescues and therefore could not advise callers that they had essentially been ruled out.
sentence1_translated: Womeɖe gbeƒã na dɔwɔlawo be womate ŋu awɔ xɔtudɔ le xɔta o, eya ta womate ŋu agblɔ na ame siwo yɔa wo be womate ŋu awɔ dɔ sia o.
sentence2: The operators knew well in advance that they had to instruct everyone to evacuate from the ground.
sentence2_translated: Dɔdzikpɔlawo nya do ŋgɔ be ele be yewoana ame sia ame naʋu le anyigba.

sentence1: Four of the 9/11 attackers were pulled into secondary border inspection, but then admitted.

sentence2: All of the 9/11 attackers were denied entry at the border.

sentence1: Four of the 9/11 attackers were pulled into secondary border inspection, but then admitted.

sentence1: This effort was going on before 9/11 and it continues on a vastly enlarged scale.

sentence2_translated: Tso 9/11 megbe la, ga si wozãna ɖe dɔa ŋu dzi ɖe edzi 120%.

sentence1: One Treasury official described CIA's posture as benign neglect toward the Foreign Terrorist Asset Tracking Center (FTATC), and characterized the CIA as believing that financial tracking had limited utility.
sentence1_translated: Gaŋutidɔwɔla aɖe ɖɔ CIA ƒe nuwɔna be enye ŋkuléle ɖe dutanyanyuigblɔlawo ƒe Asits Tracking Center (FTATC) ŋu ŋu nyuie, eye wòɖe nu si CIA la xɔ se be gaŋutiɖoɖowo ƒe viɖe le sue la fia.
sentence2: Financial tracking primarily involves examining credit card receipts and bank statements.
sentence2_translated: Ga ŋuti nyatakakawo nyanya bia be woalé ŋku ɖe nu siwo wotsɔna naa ga ame kple nu siwo woxɔna le gadzraɖoƒe ŋu.

sentence1: One Treasury official described CIA's posture as benign neglect toward the Foreign Terrorist Asset Tracking Center (FTATC), and characterized the CIA as believing that financial tracking had limited utility.
sentence1_translated: Gaŋutidɔwɔla aɖe ɖɔ CIA ƒe nuwɔna be enye ŋkuléle ɖe dutanyanyuigblɔlawo ƒe Asits Tracking Center (FTATC) ŋu ŋu nyuie, eye wòɖe nu si CIA la xɔ se be gaŋutiɖoɖowo ƒe viɖe le sue la fia.
sentence2: Some Treasury officials did not believe the CIA valued financial tracking.
sentence2_translated: Gaŋutidɔwɔƒe me tɔ aɖewo mexɔe se be CIA dea asixɔxɔ ga ŋuti nyatakakawo ŋu o.

sentence1: One Treasury official described CIA's posture as benign neglect toward the Foreign Terrorist Asset Tracking Center (FTATC), and characterized the CIA as believing that financial tracking had limited utility.

sentence1: The U.S. government readily provides copious information about spending on its military forces, including military intelligence.

sentence2: The US government spends $7 billion on military intelligence each year.

sentence1: The tragedy of the embassy bombings provided an opportunity for a full examination, across the government, of the national security threat that Bin Ladin posed.
sentence1_translated: Amedzrodzeƒea ƒe bɔmbbubu ƒe afɔku la na mɔnukpɔkpɔ dziɖuɖu blibo la katã be woadzro afɔku si gbegbe Bin Laden nye na dukɔa me dedienɔnɔ me.
sentence2: Bin Ladin's security threat should have been evident to the government after the embassy bombings.
sentence2_translated: Ele be Ben Laden ƒe dedienɔnɔ ƒe ŋɔdzidoname nadze ƒã na dziɖuɖua le dutagbedolawo ƒe bɔmbdɔwo megbe.

sentence1: The tragedy of the embassy bombings provided an opportunity for a full examination, across the government, of the national security threat that Bin Ladin posed.

sentence1: The tragedy of the embassy bombings provided an opportunity for a full examination, across the government, of the national security threat that Bin Ladin posed.

sentence1: The first NYPD ESU team entered the West Street-level lobby of the North Tower and prepared to begin climbing at about 9:15 A.M.

sentence1: Civic's revenue comes from full houses, workshop and program tuitions, facility rental, foundations, corporate sponsors and individual contributions from supporters like you.

sentence1_translated: Le fefewɔƒeawo godo la, IRT-dɔwɔlawo yia sukuxɔa me tẽe be yewoawɔ dɔ kple ɖeviwo eye yewoana woava nya fefewɔƒeawo nyuie.
sentence2: IRT artists don't do anything with kids and instead focus on adults in the community.
sentence2_translated: IRT-dɔwɔla mewɔa naneke kple ɖeviwo o, ke boŋ wotsɔa ɖe le ame tsitsiwo ŋu le nutoa me.
